title: Add
summary: Adds a numerical value to a container.
description: Produces a syntax error if the specified container does not exist or contains a non-numeric value.

parameters.description: A numerical expression to be added to the container.
A container to which the value should be added.

title: Ask
summary: Displays a dialog box with an editable text field containing the provided value.
description: When no `default-value` is provided, the `empty` string is assumed. The HyperTalk script stops executing until a user has made a choice. The text entered by the user will be put into the the `it` variable.

parameters.description: A prompt string to display in the dialog.
The default text to be displayed in the edit field.

title: Ask Password
summary: Prompts the user to enter a password in which each entered character is obscured with a bullet.
description: The value returned in the variable it is the SHA-256 cryptographic hash of the entered value, except when using the `clear` option (in which case, the plaintext is returned).

parameters.description: A prompt string to display in the dialog.
The default text to be displayed (obscured with bullets) in the edit field.

title: Answer
summary: Displays a dialog box with up to three user-selectable buttons.
description:
When no button names are provided, a single button, `OK` will be assumed.

The HyperTalk script stops executing until a user has made a choice. The name of the button chosen by the user will be put into the the `it` variable.

parameters.description: The prompt string to display in the dialog.
The name of the first (default) button.
The name of the second button.
The name of the third button.

title: Answer File
summary: Produces a file chooser dialog, prompting the user to select a single file optionally of a specified type.
description: The absolute path of the selected file will be placed in the local variable `it`. If the user cancels the dialog without choosing a file, `Cancel` will be placed in `the result`.

parameters.description: The prompt string to display in the dialog.
A file filter value; files allowed for selection must have a name ending in this value.

title: Beep
summary: Emits the system alert sound.

parameters.description: The number of times to beep.

examples.description: Beep once
Beep twice
Beep once for every button on the card layer.
examples.code: beep the number of card buttons

title: Choose Tool
summary: Chooses the specified tool from the tool palette.
description: Acceptable tool names and their corresponding numbers are as follows: `browse` (1), `oval` (14), `brush` (7), `pencil` (6), `bucket` (13), `poly[gon]` (18), `button` (2), `rect[angle]` (11), `curve` (15), `reg[ular] poly[gon]` (17), `eraser` (8), `round rect[angle]` (12), `field` (3), `select` (4), `lasso` (5), `spray [can]` (10), `line` (9), or `text` (16).

parameters.description: An expression referring to a tool either by name or number.

examples.description: Choose the paintbrush tool.

title: Click
summary: Clicks the mouse at the specified location using one or more optional modifier keys.

parameters.description: A point expression (like `10,20`) where the mouse should be clicked.
A list expression containing one or more modifier keys (`shiftKey`, `commandKey`, or `optionKey`)

examples.description: Click a button.
examples.code: click at the location of card button 1

title: Close
summary: Closes a previously opened file.

parameters.description: The name of the file to be closed.

title: Convert
summary: Converts a date and/or time from one format to another.
description: When a value is specified (rather than a container), the conversion result is placed into it.

parameters.description: A time or date expression or a container of a such an expression to be converted.

One of `seconds` (an integer value equal to the number of seconds since the epoch, Jan. 1, 1970), `dateItems` (a comma-separated list of integers in the form `year, month, day, hour, minute, second, dayNumber`), `[ adjective ] date`, or `[ adjective ] time` where `adjective` is one of `long`, `short`, `abbreviated`, `abbrev` or `english`.

title: Create Menu
summary: Creates a menu in the application menu bar.
description: You cannot create a menu with the same name as a menu that already exists. Use `reset menubar` to reset the state of the menu bar to its default configuration.

parameters.description: The name of the menu to be created.

title: Delete
summary: Deletes a menu, menu item, button or field part, or a chunk of text.

parameters.description: An expression referring to the menu, menu item, field, button or chunk to delete.

examples.description: Delete a menu from the menu bar.
Delete a menu item from a menu.
examples.code: delete menu item "My Menu Item" from menu "Customize"

examples.description: Delete a button or field.
Delete a chunk of text.
examples.code: delete the second line of card field 1

title: Dial
summary: Plays the sound of dial tones dialing a phone number.

parameters.description: An expression containing the number to be dialed.

title: Disable
summary: Disables a menu, menu item, button or field.

parameters.description: An expression referring to the menu, menu item, field, or button to disable.

examples.code: disable the first menuItem of menu "Objects"

title: Divide
summary: Divides a container by a numerical value.
description: Produces a syntax error if the specified container does not exist or contains a non-numeric value.

parameters.description: A container whose value should be divided.
A numerical value that the container should be divided by.

examples.code: divide item 2 of fld id 3 by 10.0

title: Do
summary: Executes an expression as a HyperTalk script.

parameters.description: A value to be executed as a HyperTalk script.

title: Do Menu
summary: Selects a menu item from the menu bar.
description: If two menus in the menu bar contain a menu item of the same name the first menu item will be assumed.

parameters.description: The name of a menu item to be selected.

title: Drag
summary: Clicks and drags the mouse.

parameters.description: An expression that evaluates to a point relative to the top-left corner of the card where the mouse should begin being dragged from.
An expression that evaluates to a point relative to the top-left corner of the card where the mouse should be dragged to.
One or modifier keys to be held down while dragging, one or more of `shiftKey`, `commandKey` or `optionKey`.

examples.description: Draws a diagonal line on the the card
examples.code:
choose brush tool
drag from 10,10 to 100,150 with shiftKey

title: Enable
summary: Enables a menu, menu item, button or field.

parameters.description: An expression referring to the menu, menu item, field, or button to enable.

title: Find
summary: Finds text in a field in the stack.
description:
`word`: Finds whole words in the searchable text. Search term should not contain any whitespace (if it is expected to match any text). Only whole words will match; substrings contained within a word will not.

`chars`: Finds a substring that occurs entirely within the bounds of a word (does not cross word boundaries). Search term should not include whitespace (if it is expected to match anything).

`whole`: Finds a substring that starts at the beginning of a word. Search term may contain whitespace, and search results may cross word boundaries (but will always start at a word boundary).

`string`: Finds a substring occurring anywhere in the searchable text. Search term may including whitespace, and found-text may cross word boundaries.

parameters.description: The text that should be searched for.
Optionally one of `word`, `chars`, `whole`, or `string`. When no `strategy` is specified, `whole` is assumed.
An expression referring to a field.

examples.description: Finds words beginning with `Hyper` appearing in a background field named `Card`

title: Get
summary: Gets the value of a property (or evaluates an expression) and places the value into the implicit variable `it`.

parameters.description: An expression, or property of a part, card, background, stack or HyperCard

examples.code:
get the name of this card
put it  -- places the name of this card into the message box

title: Go
summary: Navigates to a card, optionally applying a transition animation.

parameters.description: An expression referring to a card or background.
An expression referring to a visual effect (like `dissolve` or `iris open very slowly`).

examples.code: go to the second card of the last background with visual effect barn door open

title: Hide
summary: Hides a button, field, the menu bar or the card window's title bar.

parameters.description: An expression referring to the part to be hidden.
An expression referring to a window.

title: Lock Screen
summary: Prevents any changes made to the card from being visible to the user until the screen is unlocked.
description: Note that the screen automatically "unlocks" itself at idle time (as soon all scripts have completed executing).

title: Multiply
summary: Multiplies a container by a numerical value.
description: Produces a syntax error if the specified container does not exist or contains a non-numeric value.

parameters.description: A container to which the value should be added.
A numerical expression to be added to the container.

title: Next Repeat
summary: Transfers program control to the top of the currently executing `repeat` statement.
description: At any point in the loop, the `next repeat` command may be used to terminate the current iteration (that is, skip all subsequent statements) and continue looping. Similarly, the `exit repeat` command can be used to terminate the loop entirely, returning control to the next statement in the handler after `end repeat`.

title: Open File
summary: Opens a text file for reading and/or writing by script.

parameters.description: An expression referring to the name and/or path of the file to be opened.

examples.description: Opens a file in the current working directory
Opens a file elsewhere on the file system

title: Pass
summary: Terminates execution of the current handler and forwards the message being handled to the next part in the message passing order.

parameters.description: The name of the current handler (i.e., `mouseUp`). Any other name results in an error.

examples.description: If the shift key is held down when clicking this part, then the next part in the message passing order will receive `mouseUp`
examples.code:
on mouseUp
	if the shiftKey is down then pass mouseUp
end mouseUp

title: Play
summary: Plays a sound effect; optionally as a sequence of musical notes.
description:
Each musical note is written in the format `<name>[<octave>][<accidental>][<duration>]`, where:

`<name>` is a single character representing the pitch; one of `c`, `d`, `e`, `f`, `g`, `a`, `b` or `r` (for a rest note).

`<octave>` is a single-digit integer representing the note's octave; higher numbers are higher pitched. One of `0`, `1`, `2`, `3`, `4`, `5`, `6`, `7`, or `8`.

`<accidental>` is a half-note increase or decrease in pitch; of one `b` (flat, decreased pitch) or `#` (sharp, increased pitch).

`<duration>` is a single-character representation of the length of the note, plus an optional `.` to represented a dotted-note (played for one and a half times its un-dotted duration). Duration is one of `w` (whole note), `h` (half note), `q` (quarter note), `e` (eighth note), `s` (sixteenth note), `t` (thirty-second note), `x` (sixty-fourth note).

When not explicitly specified, each note "inherits" its duration and octave from the previous note played. The first note in the musical sequence is assumed to be a 4th-octave quarter note (if not explicitly noted). For example, in the musical sequence "g ce5 d", the first note (g) is played as a quarter note in the 4th octave, but the third note (d) is played as an eighth note in the 5th octave.

parameters.description: An expression evaluating to the name of a WyldCard sound effect. One of `harpsichord`, `flute` or `boing`.
An expression providing the rate at which notes are played, measured in quarter notes per minute. When not specified, a tempo of 120 is assumed.
An expression in which each word is interpreted as a musical note.

examples.description: play "Mary Had a Little Lamb" on the harpsichord
examples.code: play harpsichord "be a g a b b b r a a a r b d5 d r b4 a g a b b b b a a b a g"

title: Pop Card
summary: Navigates to the last card pushed onto the backstack.

title: Push Card
summary: Pushes a card onto the backstack.

parameters.description: An expression describing a card to be pushed.

title: Put
summary: Puts a value into a container; assigns a value to a variable, part or property.
description: When no container is specified, the message box is assumed.

parameters.description: The value to be placed into the container.
One of `into` (replaces the container's value), `before` (prepends the container with the expression), or `after` (suffixes the container with the value).
A container expression, or a chunk of a container expression, that should be assigned the value.

examples.description: Puts a value into a variable.
examples.code: put the first word of card field "Name" into firstName

examples.description: Puts a value into a chunk of a property (not legal in HyperCard).
examples.code: put 10 into item 1 of the loc of me

examples.description: Displays a value in the message window.

title: Read
summary: Reads text from a file on disk.
description:
Reads text from a file that was previously opened with the open file command into the variable `it`.

`read from file {filename}`: Reads the entire file identified by `{filename}` into memory).

`read from file {filename} for {count}`: Reads `{count}` characters from the current file position

`read from file {filename} at {position} for {count}`: Reads `{count}` characters from the file starting at `{position}`

`read file {filename} until {pattern}`: Reads the file until the given case-insensitive <pattern> is reached.

parameters.description: The value to be placed into the container.
One of `into` (replaces the container's value), `before` (prepends the container with the expression), or `after` (suffixes the container with the value).
A container expression, or a chunk of a container expression, that should be assigned the value.

examples.description: Place the entire contents of a file into `it`.

title: Reset
summary: Resets the state of a system to its default state.
description: `reset menubar` resets the state of the menubar to its default state; `reset paint` resets painting attributes (like line size, pattern, draw multiple, etc.) to their default value.

title: Select
summary: Selects a part; selects text in a field; or positions the cursor in a field.

parameters.description: An expression that refers to a field.

examples.description: Activates the button tool and highlights the first card button.
Positions the cursor at the start of the third line.
Replaces the first word with 'Uno'.

title: Set
summary: Sets the value of a property or variable.

parameters.description: The name of a WyldCard property, part property or variable.
The value to set the property to.

title: Send
summary: Sends a message to an object.
description: Sending a message to an object has the effect of invoking the handler associated with the message in the script of the target object. If the target object does not contain a handler for the message, the message will passed along the message passing hierarchy.

parameters.description: An expression representing the message (and any optional arguments) to be sent. Arguments in the message are evaluated before being sent.
The part that should receive the message.

examples.description: Send `mouseUp` to a part (to make it behave as though it were clicked by the mouse).
Sends a message with arguments (note how the second argument is HyperTalk expression).
examples.code: send "greetUser Hello, the first word of cd fld name" to this card

title: Show
summary: Shows (un-hides) a button, field, window, the menu bar or the card window's title bar.

parameters.description: An expression referring to the part to be shown.
An expression referring to a window.

title: Sort
summary: Sorts cards in the stack or text within a container.
description: When sorting text,
templates: sort the marked cards of this stack ${direction} ${style} by ${expression}

parameters.description: The element of text to be sorted, one of `chars`, `words`, `lines`, or `items`.
The container of text to be sorted.
An optional sort direction, either `ascending` or `descending` (`ascending` is assumed when no direction is specified).
Specifies how elements should be compared, one of `text`, `numeric`, `datetime`, or `international`.
An expression that is evaluated in the context of each element to determine sort order.

examples.description: Sort all the lines of a field by comparing the last word on each line to one another.
examples.code: sort the lines of field "Roster" by the last word of each

examples.description: Randomize the order of words in a variable.
examples.code: sort the words of myList by the random of 10

examples.description: Sorts all cards in the stack by the first card field.
examples.code: sort this stack by the first card field

title: Subtract
summary: Subtracts a numerical value from a container.
description: Produces a syntax error if the specified container does not exist or contains a non-numeric value.

parameters.description: A numerical expression to be added to the container.
A container from which the value should be subtracted.

title: Type
summary: Emulates the user typing keys on the keyboard.
description: The `with commandKey` form of this command emulates the user pressing command/control plus each typed character.

parameters.description: The string of characters to type on the keyboard.

examples.description: Type Command-Q to quit the application.
Paint text on the cart.
examples.code:
on mouseUp
	choose text tool
	click at 100,100
	type "Look ma! No hands!"

title: Unlock Screen
summary: Unlocks the screen, making scripted changes to the card visible to the user.
description: This command has no effect if the screen was not previously locked via the `lock screen` command. Note that the screen is automatically unlocked at idle time (as soon as all handlers have completed executing).

parameters.description: An expression specifying a visual effect, like `iris open slowly`.

title: Visual Effect
summary: Specifies the visual effect to use when unlocking the screen.
description: This command has no effect if the screen was not previously locked via the `lock screen` command.

parameters.description: An expression specifying a visual effect, like `iris open slowly`.

title: Wait
summary: Pauses script execution for a specified period of time or until a specified condition is met.
description: This command pauses only the current thread of execution; it does not affect other running scripts nor does it prevent WyldCard from sending new messages to parts.

parameters.description: The number of {timeUnit}'s to delay.
Either `seconds` or `ticks` (a _tick_ is 1/60th of a second).
The condition which should must be met in order to continue waiting (`wait while`), or to stop waiting (`wait until`).

examples.description: Delay for 10 seconds.
Delay until the user clicks the mouse.
examples.code: wait until the mouse is down

title: Write
summary: Writes text to a file on disk.
description:
Writes text into a file that was previously opened with open file.

`write {expression} to file {file}`: Writes the expression to the file, overwriting the contents of the file

`write {expression} to file {file} at end`: Appends data to the end of the given file; `at end` can also be specified as `at eof`

`write {expression} to file {file} at {position}`: Writes data to the file starting at the given `{position}`.

Note that data is not actually written to disk until the file is closed or WyldCard is quit.

parameters.description: The value to be written to the file.
An expression identifying the name of a file previously opened with the `open file` command.
An integer value representing the position in the file to write data.

title: Ask File
summary: Displays a directory chooser in which the user can enter a file name (same as a user would typically see when choosing 'Save As...' from the 'File' menu).

parameters.description: The prompt string to display in the directory chooser dialog. Note that some systems (like Mac OS X) do not display a prompt.
An expression evaluating to the default file name populated in the chooser.

title: Speak
summary: Speaks a passage of text using a computer voice.
description:
Speaking occurs asynchronously to other script actions (that is, the rest of the script continues to execute while the text is being spoken). Subsequent calls to `speak` will be enqueued and begin speaking when the current speech is complete.

Use `the speech` function to determine what (if any) text is currently being spoken; `the speech` returns the text currently being spoken or done when nothing is being spoken.

Use `the voices` to retrieve a list of available speaking voices.

parameters.description: An expression evaluating to the text that should be spoken.
An expression evaluating to name of the voice to speak with.

title: Mark
summary: Mark cards by query or logical expression.
description:
Find and mark all cards, a single card, or any card matching search criteria:
* Mark all cards in the stack: `mark all cards`
* Mark an individual card: `mark the second card`
* Mark any card on which a logical expression evaluates to true: `mark cards where the name of this card contains "special"`
* Mark all cards containing found text on the card or within a specific field on the card: `mark cards by finding "WyldCard" in card field 1`

parameters.description: An expression that evaluates to a card. For example, `card three`
An expression evaluating to a boolean (true or false) value.
The text that should be searched for.
Optionally one of `word`, `chars`, `whole`, or `string`. When no `strategy` is specified, `whole` is assumed.
An expression evaluating to a field where text should be searched. If the expression does not evaluate to a valid field on the card, the card will not be marked.

title: Unmark
summary: Unmark cards by query or logical expression.
description:
Find and unmark all cards, a single card, or any card matching search criteria:
* Unmark all cards in the stack: `unmark all cards`
* Unmark an individual card: `unmark the second card`
* Unmark any card on which a logical expression evaluates to true: `unmark cards where the name of this card contains "special"`
* Unmark all cards containing found text on the card or within a specific field on the card: `unmark cards by finding "WyldCard" in card field 1`

parameters.description: An expression that evaluates to a card. For example, `card three`
An expression evaluating to a boolean (true or false) value.
The text that should be searched for.
Optionally one of `word`, `chars`, `whole`, or `string`. When no `strategy` is specified, `whole` is assumed.
An expression evaluating to a field where text should be searched. If the expression does not evaluate to a valid field on the card, the card will not be unmarked.

title: Tab Key
summary: Equivalent to typing `tab` on the keyboard.

title: Enter Key
summary: Equivalent to typing `enter` on the keyboard.

title: Control Key
summary: Equivalent to pressing the `control` key on the keyboard.

title: Enter In Field
summary: Equivalent to typing `enter` into the in-focus field. Has no effect if a text field is not currently focused.

title: Command Key Down
summary: Equivalent to pressing the `command` key on the keyboard.

title: Debug Checkpoint
summary: Activates the HyperTalk debugger.
description: Pauses execution of the script and causes the HyperTalk debugger to open, highlighting this statement. Has no effect when executed from the message window.

title: Arrow Key
summary: Equivalent to pressing one of the directional arrow keys on the keyboard.

parameters.description: An expression evaluating to a direction; one of `up`, `down`, `left` or `right`.

title: Save
summary: Saves the current, or a specified stack, to disk.
description: Saves a copy of the current stack, or a specified stack, to a given file. If an error occurs, `the result` will contain an error message. Note that stacks are always saved with the `.stack` file extension. If the given filename does not end in `.stack` then this extension will be automatically appended to the filename.

parameters.description: An expression that evaluates to a stack. For example, `stack "My Stack"`
An expression evaluating to a file or a path to a file, for example `"/users/bill/mystack"`.
